Disease.content:
Please identify the "Disease" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Disease". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: The changes in renal prostaglandin synthesis were accompanied by evidence of renal damage in aspirin - treated jj but not jJ rats as evidenced by : increased incidence and severity of hematuria ( p less than 0 . 01 ) ; increased serum creatinine ( p less than 0 . 05 ) ; and increase in outer medullary histopathologic lesions ( p less than 0 . 005 compared to either sham - treated jj or aspirin - treated jJ ) .

Let's think step by step.

| Disease |
| --- |
| Hematuria |
| Creatinine |
| Histopathologic lesions |

Note: These are not necessarily three separate diseases, but rather three different ways in which renal damage can manifest. Hematuria refers to the presence of blood in the urine, creatinine is a waste product that can accumulate in the blood when the kidneys are not functioning properly, and histopathologic lesions refer to abnormalities in the tissue of the kidneys that can be detected through a biopsy.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Disease" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Disease".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Disease |
| --- |
| Hematuria |

The other two entities mentioned in the paragraph, "creatinine" and "histopathologic lesions", do not clearly refer to diseases. Creatinine is a waste product that can accumulate in the blood when the kidneys are not functioning properly, but it is not a disease itself. Histopathologic lesions refer to abnormalities in the tissue of the kidneys that can be detected through a biopsy, but they are also not a specific disease.

Therefore, the only valid disease entity in the paragraph is "Hematuria", which refers to the presence of blood in the urine.

| Chemical |

Explanation:
